title: Denim Bedding Is the Fashion-Forward Essential You Need to Elevate Your Bedroom
description: We’re in full support of the trend transforming your bedscape in Cowboy Carter fashion
author: Nashia Baker
excerpt: Denim bedding is the latest design trend destined to elevate your bedroom in relaxed yet inviting fashion. Here, we tapped designers to breakdown the category
text: All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links.In a world where home decor often falls in line with fashion, it’s no wonder that denim-colored bedding is the latest trend to hit the interiors scene. For me, the mere thought of the trend all started with listening to Beyoncé’s “Levii’s Jeans” on repeat, constantly looking at Ticketmaster to find the best seats to the Cowboy Carter tour, and envisioning my denim look for the concert. As I sat on my bed and thought about how our homes are truly an extension of our own senses of style, this got me thinking: Is it possible to dress my bed in denim? You might be surprised to know that the answer is yes. There’s an entire category of bedding dedicated to breathable chambrays and indigo linens that mirror the very look and feel of a pair of well-worn blue jeans. Plus, they are machine-washable and designed for all season wear. After talking with designers with their fingers on the pulse, I’m not the only one who’s spotted denim hues on the rise in the home space.Serena & Lily Portofino Linen Bedding SetQuince European Linen Duvet Cover SetElise McMahon, founder of LikeMindedObjects, has been working with denim across fashion and furniture for nearly a decade since launching her New York–based business—and she’s even weighed in on related topics for AD, including the infamous jouch. According to her expertise, this fabric is way more versatile than it gets credit for. “Denim is unique in its combination of utilitarian strength making it long lasting but also can be experienced in a way almost like leather, buttery and soft, depending on the weight and feel,” she says.In McMahon’s eyes, this material is trending in the home space for the same reason it’s trending in fashion: sustainability. “It’s just as I think natural materials are a priority for people in furniture and clothing but especially bedding, in my opinion synthetics have no place in bedding covers, such an intimate space where we spend literally a third of our lives,” she says.But where did this trend really come from, exactly? Trend reports and designers have mentioned this material as one to watch over the last year, says AD PRO Directory designer Lisa Shaffer, the CEO and creative director of Lisa & Leroy. “Since 2024, there’s been a clear rise in denim-inspired colors and materials,” she says, adding that “soft, washed blues and fabrics with a relaxed, lived-in texture are showing up more in both paint and textiles.” Shaffer credits this shift in the bedroom to shoppers’ desire to create a calming, natural sleep oasis. And because blue is a serene choice all around for a bedroom, these denim-centric shades offer a feel that’s timeless and inviting.An inky linen blue duvet echoes the Akari lamp and accents the plaster and cork-covered guest room of Troye Sivan’s soulful Melbourne home. Photo: Anson Smart; Styling: Joseph GardnerAs I’ve searched across sites from AD-favorite bedding brands, I couldn’t help but notice that tried-and-true retailers like Quince and Serena & Lily are getting in on the action with picks that are strikingly similar to designs you’d find in a fashion catalog, and for good reason. Like linen sheets, AD PRO Directory designer Jasmine Artis, owner and principal designer of J’Miracle Designs, says what she loves about a denim-like material in home interiors is that it “provides durability, texture, and a relaxed aesthetic.” What’s more, she describes it as casual luxury: “It appears laid-back but still feels thoughtfully styled, especially when paired with layered textures.”When searching for denim-centric bedding, Artis recommends gathering inspiration from your favorite pair of jeans with attributes such as pre-washed fabrics, contrast stitching, indigo blue hues, or just plain-out comfort. “Suppliers have responded to this trend by offering a range of denim bedding products from duvets, comforters, rugs, and even lamp shades,” she says. Artis suggests looking for high-quality materials like washed denim, cotton chambray, cotton twill, recycled denim, or cotton linen blends on care labels to ensure easy care (typically a machine wash and tumble dry) and that they’re designed to last—just like your go-to pair of pants. Shaffer adds that materials like the aforementioned fabrics not only help capture the look and texture of denim but they also offer the breathability that you’ll need to comfortably catch some z’s.When it comes to styling, don’t be afraid to experiment. Artis recommends pairing bedding with neutrals for a clean look, as this keeps the space airy and modern while still allowing the denim to be the centerpiece in the bedroom. Otherwise, she recommends pairing lightwash blue colors with textures, like sherpa or fur throws and velvet decorative pillows."Colorwashing is having a real moment in interior design right now,” Shaffer adds. “A fully tonal blue room can be incredibly striking, especially when layered with different textures and shades.” To create a Canadian tuxedo-like sleep setup that makes the space feel completely cohesive, she points to sourcing a blue rug for starters and recommends building from there for tonal depth.West Elm Faux Fur Chinchilla ThrowRuggable Impasto Slate Blue RugThe Citizenry Naveta Velvet PillowIf you want to go the deep blue denim route, Artis notes that this instantly brings a “bold, cozy, yet grounded vibe to a bedroom.” She loves to pair this color scheme with lots of layering. Think velvet and wool throws and bedspreads in rich colors like midnight blue, olive, or aubergine. “Also, I like to incorporate woods and brass elements in which the denim creates a warm balance,” she says.Parachute Linen Duvet Cover SetRejuvenation Atticus LED Table LampLinoto Aubergine Linen Sheet SetWhile all of these experts know a thing or two about styling with this fabric, they all just recommend letting your bedscape become your playground. “I typically don’t ascribe to do’s and don’ts,” says Shaffer. “Interior design is all about having fun and playing around with the textures and colors that are exciting to you and make you feel warm and welcome in your space."As for me, I’m going back to listening to “Levii’s Jeans” and updating my own wish list to make this trend a reality for my bedroom. From a comforter set to pillow shams, here are even more picks to inspire your shopping journey:The Citizenry Stonewashed Linen Curated Bed BundleCompany Cotton Washed Denim Duvet CoverPottery Barn Teen Denim Duvet CoverArticle Elmer Large PillowSimple&Opulence French Linen Duvet Cover SetWest Elm Cotton Cloud Jersey Duvet CoverPottery Barn Teen Denim Stitch QuiltAnnie Selke Kodi Batik Duvet Cover
html:
All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links.

In a world where home decor often falls in line with fashion, it’s no wonder that denim-colored bedding is the latest trend to hit the interiors scene. For me, the mere thought of the trend all started with listening to Beyoncé’s “Levii’s Jeans” on repeat, constantly looking at Ticketmaster to find the best seats to the Cowboy Carter tour, and envisioning my denim look for the concert. As I sat on my bed and thought about how our homes are truly an extension of our own senses of style, this got me thinking: Is it possible to dress my bed in denim? You might be surprised to know that the answer is yes. There’s an entire category of bedding dedicated to breathable chambrays and indigo linens that mirror the very look and feel of a pair of well-worn blue jeans. Plus, they are machine-washable and designed for all season wear. After talking with designers with their fingers on the pulse, I’m not the only one who’s spotted denim hues on the rise in the home space.

Serena & Lily Portofino Linen Bedding Set

Quince European Linen Duvet Cover Set

Elise McMahon, founder of LikeMindedObjects, has been working with denim across fashion and furniture for nearly a decade since launching her New York–based business—and she’s even weighed in on related topics for AD, including the infamous jouch. According to her expertise, this fabric is way more versatile than it gets credit for. “Denim is unique in its combination of utilitarian strength making it long lasting but also can be experienced in a way almost like leather, buttery and soft, depending on the weight and feel,” she says.

In McMahon’s eyes, this material is trending in the home space for the same reason it’s trending in fashion: sustainability. “It’s just as I think natural materials are a priority for people in furniture and clothing but especially bedding, in my opinion synthetics have no place in bedding covers, such an intimate space where we spend literally a third of our lives,” she says.

But where did this trend really come from, exactly? Trend reports and designers have mentioned this material as one to watch over the last year, says AD PRO Directory designer Lisa Shaffer, the CEO and creative director of Lisa & Leroy. “Since 2024, there’s been a clear rise in denim-inspired colors and materials,” she says, adding that “soft, washed blues and fabrics with a relaxed, lived-in texture are showing up more in both paint and textiles.” Shaffer credits this shift in the bedroom to shoppers’ desire to create a calming, natural sleep oasis. And because blue is a serene choice all around for a bedroom, these denim-centric shades offer a feel that’s timeless and inviting.

As I’ve searched across sites from AD-favorite bedding brands, I couldn’t help but notice that tried-and-true retailers like Quince and Serena & Lily are getting in on the action with picks that are strikingly similar to designs you’d find in a fashion catalog, and for good reason. Like linen sheets, AD PRO Directory designer Jasmine Artis, owner and principal designer of J’Miracle Designs, says what she loves about a denim-like material in home interiors is that it “provides durability, texture, and a relaxed aesthetic.” What’s more, she describes it as casual luxury: “It appears laid-back but still feels thoughtfully styled, especially when paired with layered textures.”

When searching for denim-centric bedding, Artis recommends gathering inspiration from your favorite pair of jeans with attributes such as pre-washed fabrics, contrast stitching, indigo blue hues, or just plain-out comfort. “Suppliers have responded to this trend by offering a range of denim bedding products from duvets, comforters, rugs, and even lamp shades,” she says. Artis suggests looking for high-quality materials like washed denim, cotton chambray, cotton twill, recycled denim, or cotton linen blends on care labels to ensure easy care (typically a machine wash and tumble dry) and that they’re designed to last—just like your go-to pair of pants. Shaffer adds that materials like the aforementioned fabrics not only help capture the look and texture of denim but they also offer the breathability that you’ll need to comfortably catch some z’s.

When it comes to styling, don’t be afraid to experiment. Artis recommends pairing bedding with neutrals for a clean look, as this keeps the space airy and modern while still allowing the denim to be the centerpiece in the bedroom. Otherwise, she recommends pairing lightwash blue colors with textures, like sherpa or fur throws and velvet decorative pillows.

"Colorwashing is having a real moment in interior design right now,” Shaffer adds. “A fully tonal blue room can be incredibly striking, especially when layered with different textures and shades.” To create a Canadian tuxedo-like sleep setup that makes the space feel completely cohesive, she points to sourcing a blue rug for starters and recommends building from there for tonal depth.

West Elm Faux Fur Chinchilla Throw

Ruggable Impasto Slate Blue Rug

The Citizenry Naveta Velvet Pillow

If you want to go the deep blue denim route, Artis notes that this instantly brings a “bold, cozy, yet grounded vibe to a bedroom.” She loves to pair this color scheme with lots of layering. Think velvet and wool throws and bedspreads in rich colors like midnight blue, olive, or aubergine. “Also, I like to incorporate woods and brass elements in which the denim creates a warm balance,” she says.

Parachute Linen Duvet Cover Set

Rejuvenation Atticus LED Table Lamp

Linoto Aubergine Linen Sheet Set

While all of these experts know a thing or two about styling with this fabric, they all just recommend letting your bedscape become your playground. “I typically don’t ascribe to do’s and don’ts,” says Shaffer. “Interior design is all about having fun and playing around with the textures and colors that are exciting to you and make you feel warm and welcome in your space."

As for me, I’m going back to listening to “Levii’s Jeans” and updating my own wish list to make this trend a reality for my bedroom. From a comforter set to pillow shams, here are even more picks to inspire your shopping journey:

The Citizenry Stonewashed Linen Curated Bed Bundle

Company Cotton Washed Denim Duvet Cover

Pottery Barn Teen Denim Duvet Cover

Article Elmer Large Pillow

Simple&Opulence French Linen Duvet Cover Set

West Elm Cotton Cloud Jersey Duvet Cover

Pottery Barn Teen Denim Stitch Quilt

Annie Selke Kodi Batik Duvet Cover
